article:
The 'hand' is a non-SI unit of measurement of length, now normally used only for
the measurement of the height of horses in some English-speaking countries,
including Australia, Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States. With origins in ancient Egypt, it was originally based on the
breadth of a human hand. It is today equal to four inches, and thus, following
the adoption of the international inch in 1959, it is equal to exactly
10.16 centimetres. It may be abbreviated to "h" or "hh".
Although measurements between whole hands are usually expressed in what appears
to be decimal format, the subdivision of the hand is not decimal but is in base
4, so subdivisions after the radix point are in quarters of a hand, which are
inches. Thus, 62 inches is fifteen and a half hands, or 15.2
hh (normally said as "fifteen-two", or occasionally in full as "fifteen hands
two inches")
categories: Customary units of measurement in the United States
